title: Infrastructure Negotiators Try to Overcome Late Hurdles
summary: Lawmakers had set Monday as target for finishing bipartisan talks. WASHINGTON-A push to complete a roughly $1 trillion infrastructure agreement hit a series of hurdles Monday, as aides squabbled over funding for water infrastructure and how to apply a requirement that federal contractors pay their employees a locally prevailing wage, among other issues.

title: Tesla Overcomes Chip Shortage to Post Record Profit
summary: Electric-vehicle maker has faced growing competition and supply disruptions as it works to open new assembly plants. Tesla Inc. generated a record quarterly profit as the car maker largely sidestepped the effects of a global chip shortage that has constricted production for many global auto makers.

title: Aon, Willis Towers Scrap $30 Billion Merger
summary: Justice Department alleged the combination of insurance brokers would eliminate competition. Aon PLC and Willis Towers Watson PLC abandoned a more than $30 billion tie-up to create the world's largest insurance broker, deciding it wasn't worth pursuing in the face of Justice Department opposition to the merger.

title: Afghanistan on the Brink
summary: The U.S. resumes bombing, but Biden needs to do more.. The U.S. has resumed bombing in Afghanistan, a tacit admission that the Taliban are advancing faster than the Biden Administration anticipated. The U.S. military warned the White House this would happen, and the outlook is grim if President Biden doesn't change course on his total withdrawal.

title: A New National Climate Army
summary: Democrats want to pay young Americans to tell you how to behave.. As the U.S. recovers from a pandemic, with workers in services and manufacturing in short supply across the economy, here's what no one sensible thinks America urgently needs: a huge new federal Civilian Climate Corps.

title: Mass Spending for Mass Transit
summary: Democrats want the GOP to rescue big-city rail and public unions.. Democrats are accusing Republicans of holding up the Senate infrastructure deal over funding for mass transit. Here's what's really going on: Republicans have bowed to most Democratic demands. But now Democrats are also insisting that they acquiesce to spending ever more to rescue broken rail and bus systems in big liberal cities.

title: How to Avert Disaster in Afghanistan
summary: The least the U.S. can do is offer air support, intel and ensure proper logistics and maintenance contracting.. The situation in Afghanistan is deteriorating rapidly. As the U.S. and its international partners withdrew military forces over the past few months, the Taliban roughly tripled the territory under its control. If the U.S. and allies don't take urgent action, the world will bear witness to a disaster.

title: 'Hyper Education' Review: Studying Hard and Blamed for It
summary: Asian families are often mocked or faulted for their commitment to academics and for enrolling their children in after-school learning programs.. A recent ad for the Kumon learning centers begins: "In the past year, it's been hard to know if your child's learning has been on track and advancing." Parents are then encouraged to sign their children up for lessons after school to ensure that the students don't fall behind. Of course, after-school education was growing even before the pandemic. (Kumon has reported annual revenue to be roughly $40 billion, with nearly 300,000 students nationwide.) But it may well grow even more now,as parents worry about the effects of disrupted school schedules and remote learning.

title: No-Show Lawmakers Use Covid as an Excuse
summary: Proxy voting was meant to protect us from infection. It's become a way of ducking responsibility.. The House returned to Washington last week following another virtual committee work period. But some representatives didn't bother showing up. Members can still cast votes by proxy and attend hearings virtually, thanks to House protocols in place since the start of the coronavirus pandemic. This approach to House operations is ineffective and abused by members of both parties.

title: The Revolt of the Unwoke
summary: Three progressive San Francisco school board members are targeted for a recall.. If the land of woke has a capital, it's San Francisco. Which makes it all the more extraordinary that the City by the Bay has now become ground zero for a revolt by unwoke moms and dads.

title: Vaccine Mandates Imposed on Some Government Workers
summary: California, New York City will require government workers to be vaccinated or tested weekly as Delta variant pushes new cases higher. A significant uptick in Covid-19 cases across the U.S. is leading to new vaccination mandates for public employees, with the Department of Veterans Affairs on Monday becoming the first federal agency, California the first state, and New York the first major city to announce requirements for their workers.

title: My Phone Calls Are Holding Me Captive
summary: I've developed a hang-up about the phrase 'I'll let you go.'. I never knew I was so frequently held captive. Apparently it happens at least twice a day, at least five days a week. Sometimes I'm in my office, other times I'm at home, or perhaps I'm in the car. I learn of my predicament over the phone or via video chat, as the conversation is ending. That's when I hear: "I'll let you go."

title: Tokyo Lobs the Ball Back at Beijing
summary: Japanese words and military spending issue a blunt reminder to China on Taiwan.. Japan's Jun Mizutani and Mima Ito shocked reigning champion China by winning the gold medal in mixed doubles table tennis Monday. But Tokyo's increasingly aggressive pushback against Chinese pressure on Taiwan is causing more heartburn in Beijing than lost Olympic glory.

title: Chevron Foe Steven Donziger Found Guilty of Contempt in Ecuador Saga
summary: Ruling marks latest twist in decadeslong legal battle involving disbarred attorney who pursued environmental claims against oil giant. Disbarred attorney Steven Donziger was found guilty of six counts of criminal contempt of court, the latest twist in a nearly three-decade crusade against Chevron Corp. that began as an attempt to prove the oil company caused environmental harm in Ecuador.

title: Cuban Protesters Get Prison Sentences, House Arrest in Summary Trials
summary: Among those sentenced are dozens of independent professionals, artists and journalists. Scores of Cubans who participated in recent mass protests have received sentences of up to one year in prison or house arrest in summary trials without due process, civil rights activists and relatives of detainees say.

title: Intel Sets Plan to Again Become World's Premier Chip Company
summary: CEO Pat Gelsinger maps path to catch up with Asian rivals with series of increasingly powerful chips featuring tinier transistors. The race is on at Intel Corp. as the semiconductor giant pledges to return to the top of its game, committing to produce the world's best chips within four years.

title: Bitcoin Jumps to a Six-Week High
summary: Investors attribute rally to short positions being liquidated and speculation Amazon may be venturing into digital currencies. The price of jumped to a six-week high Monday, with some investors attributing the rally to short positions being liquidated and speculation that Amazon . com Inc. may be venturing into digital currencies.

title: FDA Wants Larger Number of Children in Vaccine Tests
summary: Bigger pool of those 5 to 11 years is seen aiding discovery of any side effects, like the heart condition myocarditis. The Food and Drug Administration has raised the minimum number of young children that should be in Covid-19 vaccine trials to better detect any side effects, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Biden and the Possibility of Nothing
summary: Considering the upside for taxpayers.. This column has been arguing since January that President Joe Biden could succeed by doing nothing to disrupt a rebounding economy. To date he hasn't chosen to pursue this strategy but today brings fresh hope that Mr. Biden and the country can thrive in the months ahead.

title: 'You Are Here' Review: Everyone Into the Pool
summary: A sculpture, sound and performance installation at Lincoln Center's Hearst Plaza fuses professional dance with first-person storytelling from 'civilians.'. New York

title: Dow, S&P 500 Set Records
summary: Bitcoin soars on speculation that Amazon.com may venture into digital currencies. U.S. stocks rose slightly Monday to set closing highs ahead of a busy week of earnings from technology companies.

title: Lucid Shares Climb 11% in First Trading Day After SPAC Merger
summary: The electric-vehicle startup is the latest company in the sector to consummate a blank-check merger. Shares of Lucid Group climbed 11% in their first day of trading on Monday after the electric-vehicle company completed a blank-check merger ahead of plans to launch production later this year.

title: Hasbro Stocks Up on Toys to Work Around Shipping Constraints
summary: Higher prices, which the toy maker announced this spring, are going into effect this quarter to offset rising input and freight costs. Hasbro Inc. is sourcing more of its toys earlier from various countries as it anticipates port congestion and ocean-capacity constraints in the second half of the year, executives said.

title: Biden Administration Names Its First U.S. Attorneys
summary: Eight nominees include Boston district attorney Rachael Rollins; Matthew Graves tapped to head D.C. office prosecuting Jan. 6 Capitol riot cases. WASHINGTON-President Biden put forward his first set of nominees to lead U.S. attorneys' offices across the country, a group that includes a former fraud and public-corruption prosecutor who would oversee hundreds of criminal cases stemming from the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

title: Garland Posed High Hurdle for Aon-Willis Deal
summary: Attorney general shares view that antitrust laws are central to 'American economic liberty'. WASHINGTON-The decision by insurance brokers Aon PLC and Willis Towers Watson PLC to scuttle their $30 billion merger underscores the hard line the Biden administration is forming on antitrust and competition issues.

title: Utz Promotes Accounting Executive to CFO Role Amid Broader Reshuffling
summary: Ajay Kataria is set to succeed Cary Devore, who has been named chief operating officer. Snack maker Utz Brands Inc. promoted an accounting executive to the role of finance chief as it builds out its management team nearly a year after its listing on the public markets.

title: Marine Core (Tuesday Crossword, July 27)
Tunisia Political Crisis Deepens as President Tightens Grip on Power
summary: President Kais Saied dismissed top officials, and the speaker of parliament called on Tunisians to unite 'against this coup attempt'. Tunisia plunged deeper into political crisis on Monday as President Kais Saied tightened his grip on power, dismissing top government officials and deploying military forces around the prime minister's office in a dramatic move that opponents called a coup attempt.

title: Texas and Oklahoma Bolt From the Big 12 Conference
summary: The Longhorns and Sooners are eyeing a move to the powerful Southeastern Conference, which would set off a scramble by everyone else to find a spot in the most affluent and prestigious conferences. Texas and Oklahoma have informed the Big 12 that they intend to leave the league, setting off what is likely to be a jolting realignment of the sport in which powerful schools position themselves to jump from one conference to another in search of bigger paydays and more prestigious opponents.

title: Healthcare Workers Ask Employers to Mandate Covid-19 Vaccines
summary: Dozens of groups said shots should be mandatory in care facilities. Dozens of groups representing doctors, nurses and other medical workers called on their employers to mandate Covid-19 vaccination among employees in healthcare facilities, as the Delta variant pushes up hospitalizations in much of the country.

title: Long Covid May Qualify as Disability, Biden Administration Says
summary: White House raises possibility of required special accommodations for people with virus's long-term symptoms. WASHINGTON-President Biden said certain Americans dealing with long-term symptoms of Covid-19, commonly referred to as long Covid, may have a disability under civil-rights laws protecting them from discrimination.

title: Judge Extends Facebook Antitrust Deadline
summary: Agency has until Aug. 19 to amend suit after judge's earlier dismissal. WASHINGTON-The Federal Trade Commission has until Aug. 19 to file an amended version of its antitrust lawsuit against Facebook Inc. after a judge granted the agency an extension.

title: How Simone Biles Performs Her Most Difficult Gymnastics Moves at the Olympics
summary: The physics behind the extraordinary feats Biles is expected to pull off at the Summer Games. Simone Biles-widely considered the greatest gymnast of all time-is a favorite to take as many as four individual titles at her second consecutive Olympic Games, and to boost the U.S. to another team title, too.

title: Why First-Time Homebuyers Are Missing Out on Homes-and Long-Term Wealth
summary: The supply of entry-level housing across the U.S. is near a five-decade low, says Freddie Mac. Homeownership has long been thought of as a money milestone. But for those looking to buy a starter home in this year's hot housing market, a shortage in the supply of entry-level housing-which Freddie Mac defines as homes up to 1,400 square feet-is complicating the search. Here's what you need to know.

title: How Alex Moss Became the Go-To Jeweler for Tyler, the Creator and Other Rappers
summary: At just 29, Mr. Moss is already renowned for his resplendent diamond-laden chains, which sell for as much as $500,000. FRESH OFF THE release of his chart-topping album "Call Me If You Get Lost," Tyler, the Creator arrived at June's BET Awards wearing a gigundo necklace made of gumball-like orbs encrusted all around with colored diamonds. Hanging from the piece, which was crafted by New York jeweler Alex Moss, was a similarly diamond-bedazzled statuette of "Bunny Hop," the rapper's bellhop alter ego. Tyler said the gem-laden necklace was so heavy that it wasn't "fun to wear," but its majesty made it worth it. "The concept, the colors...no one this year is going to have a better piece," Tyler said.

title: Tesla's Closest Imitator Is Just Starting Its Journey
summary: The company launched on the stock market Monday. The next milestone will be more important.. Tesla wannabe Lucid Motors has reached the stock market. Now comes the hard part.

title: The Revolution May Come for Mark Zuckerberg
summary: As Robespierre and Trotsky discovered, allies are always expendable in the larger struggle.. As Robespierre and Trotsky perhaps reflected in their final moments, all revolutions end up eating their own. Today's cultural revolutionaries of the American left haven't-yet-turned on their former allies with quite the same vigor as did their Jacobin and Bolshevik forebears, but the signs are there and Mark Zuckerberg especially could be forgiven for starting to feel a little figurative tightness around the throat.

title: A Socialist Chairs the Budget Committee
summary: Sanders's 'pragmatic' proposal would spend $1 trillion more on healthcare without any cost cuts.. President Obama sold the Affordable Care Act by claiming it would reduce the average family's healthcare costs by $2,500 a year. Instead, premiums have risen unabated, and healthcare spending has grown as a portion of the economy. But a dozen years later, Democrats aren't even bothering to make such a practical case as they propose increasing health spending by at least half a trillion dollars over the coming decade.

title: Civilian Deaths, Injuries Surge in Afghanistan, U.N. Report Says
summary: Casualties rose sharply as U.S. began withdrawing troops and the Taliban stepped up rural offensive. KABUL-Civilian casualties of war in Afghanistan surged in the first half of the year as the U.S. began withdrawing forces from the country and the Taliban launched an offensive that swept through remote provinces, the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan said in a report Monday.

title: Ex-Wife of Billionaire Bill Gross Lists Beverly Hills Estate for $38 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. Sue Gross, ex-wife of retired billionaire bond king Bill Gross, is listing a Beverly Hills estate for $38 million.

title: A Midcentury Modern Refuge in Beverly Hills
summary: The home of Sue Gross, ex-wife of retired billionaire bond king Bill Gross, was previously owned by Ellen DeGeneres and her wife Portia de Rossi.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Stagwell, MDC Partners Agree to Merger Following Shareholder Dispute
summary: MDC shareholders are set to own 31% of combined company, rebranded Stagwell Inc., more than initially offered. Shareholders in MDC Partners Inc. and Stagwell Media LP on Monday agreed to merge the two advertising and marketing companies after resolving a dispute that had threatened to derail the deal.

title: Lebanon Nominates Another Former Prime Minister to Form Government
summary: The billionaire was tapped by President Michel Aoun after two previous attempts failed amid an economic crisis. BEIRUT-Lebanon's political factions nominated billionaire businessman and former Prime Minister Najib Mikati to form the country's next government, in an attempt to break a monthslong deadlock after two previous attempts were abandoned.

title: Investors Aren't Playing Defense, but the Military Splurge Isn't Over
summary: Lockheed Martin's cheap valuation may overestimate the extent of defense budget cuts. Weapons makers are struggling in the current equity market, but their defensive perimeter may be more secure than it seems.

title: Covid Treatment Options Remain Elusive, Despite Months of Effort and Rising Delta Cases
summary: Resume Subscription. Nearly a year and a half into the pandemic, researchers are still struggling to find effective, easy-to-use drugs to treat Covid-19.

title: China Tech Stocks Slump as Regulators Apply Fresh Pressure
summary: Selloff sends Hong Kong's flagship tech index sharply lower. A new onslaught of regulatory actions in China rattled investors Monday, hammering big tech stocks and fueling a fresh crash in the shares of companies that organize online and in-person tutoring for Chinese schoolchildren.

title: India Monsoon Flooding Death Toll Climbs
summary: Heavy rains in western state of Maharashtra trigger mudslides, killing at least 150 people. NEW DELHI-The head of a village on India's west coast was celebrating his birthday last week when a few local boys ran to his house with a message: The river that flowed through the village was so high that houses were being swept away from the banks.

title: U.S. to Keep Covid-19 Travel Restrictions Due to Delta Variant, Official Says
summary: Administration officials discussed the issue at a senior-level White House meeting on Friday, the official said. WASHINGTON-The U.S. won't lift restrictions on international travel at this point, a White House official said Monday, citing rising coronavirus cases at home and abroad caused by the Delta variant.

title: As Taliban Advance, Thousands of Afghans Seek Refuge in Turkey
summary: Resume Subscription. VAN, Turkey-When the Taliban swept across northern Afghanistan in June, burning shops and executing government soldiers, Jamal Naser and Farida Kohi fled with their four children.

title: Detroit Bumbles Over 12 Million Imported Bees
summary: An effort to help urban farms with pollination has riled critics who are rushing to the defense of Detroit's native bees; then there are the humans. DETROIT-The Core City neighborhood of Detroit is getting 300,000 new residents next year. That is welcome news for some locals living in an area where the population has shrunk. But these newcomers don't pay taxes or mix well with some of the locals-especially when they sting.

title: The Really Critical Infrastructure Need: American-Made Semiconductors
summary: About 40% of new chip-production capacity projected to be added in the next decade will be in China. The push for two big infrastructure bills-one bipartisan, the other a much bigger one pushed by Democrats alone-is getting all the attention in Washington right now, and for good reason. Trillions of dollars hang in the balance, as does much of President Biden's agenda and the question of whether Washington can do anything big in a bipartisan fashion any more.

title: Russia's Male Gymnasts Take Team Gold for a Country Not Officially Present at the Games
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Russian gymnasts won the Olympic men's team title, breaking a 20-year reign by China and Japan and notching a particularly coveted gold medal for the ostracized delegation that is required to compete as the Russian Olympic Committee due to a sprawling doping scandal.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Pioneer BioNTech Plans Malaria, Tuberculosis Shots
summary: German company aims to help continent that imports 99% of its vaccines develop local production facilities. BioNTech SE said it would invest some of the profits from the Covid-19 vaccine it markets with Pfizer Inc. into developing shots for malaria and tuberculosis in Africa, part of the German company's plan to establish a large production hub for innovative medicines on the continent.

title: Foreign Purchases of U.S. Homes Fall to New Low
summary: Foreigners bought $54.4 billion in U.S. residential real estate in the year ended in March, down 27%, according to NAR report. Foreign purchases of U.S. homes declined for a fourth straight year as the Covid-19 pandemic sharply limited international travel.

title: Critical Race Theory Becomes Key to GOP Campaign Strategy in Virginia
summary: Resume Subscription. BROADLANDS, Va.-The race for Virginia governor has emerged as the nation's first prominent test of voter reaction to the debate around critical race theory, with the GOP nominee seeking to tap into visceral pushback, largely among Republican voters, to the idea that America is structurally tilted in favor of white people.

title: The Course and Consequences of Inflation
summary: The growth rate in the money supply has been slowing substantially.. Aharon Friedman and Stephan Miran's "The Inflation Tax on Capital" (op-ed, July 19) nicely illustrates the randomness of the effective capital-gains tax rates caused by inflation. Even if the legislated rates are progressive, a high-income taxpayer may still pay a lower effective rate on real capital gains than would a lower-income taxpayer if the latter held an asset during a long inflationary period.

title: Full FDA Approval Is Needed to Overcome Vaccine Hesitancy
summary: As the Delta variant spreads, what is the agency waiting for?. Instead of blaming Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for "plateauing rates of vaccination in the U.S." ("Facebook Is Biden's Vaccine Scapegoat," Review & Outlook, July 20), President Biden should be urging the Food and Drug Administration to make a prompt decision on full approval for the Covid vaccines in use. To date these vaccines have received only emergency provisional approval.

title: Danger on the Catholic Right and Left for Pope Francis
summary: How will traditionalists react given the aberrations prevalent in Germany?. Francis X. Rocca's question "Is Pope Francis Leading the Church To a Schism?" (Review, July 17) is both moot and premature. The issues regarding human sexuality are de facto accepted by a large number of Germans. Official recognition by a synod would be counterproductive and unwise for the German hierarchy. It would push Rome into a corner, forcing a response that would divide the church. A more diplomatic solution, preferred by the Vatican, is to turn a blind eye, preserving a facade of unity.

title: A Legal Immigrant Views the Prospect of Another Amnesty
summary: Fifteen or 20 years down the line, are we going to have the same conversation for the minors who are arriving right now?. In your editorial "An Immigration Reboot for Biden" (July 19), you give your support to the legalization of DACA recipients. On the surface, this position makes sense. If the legislation passes, it will protect millions. But 15 or 20 years down the line, are we going to have the same conversation for the minors who are arriving right now? Border crossings have risen to their highest levels in years, and it's unclear how many people will be offered asylum. Once the undocumented children grow up, they too will seek legal status and work permits and all the privileges being fought for today. We'll be right back to where we started.

title: Chinese Officials Blame U.S. for Stalemate in High-Level Talks
summary: Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman is most senior U.S. official to visit China under the Biden administration. TAIPEI-Senior U.S. and Chinese officials sparred over Covid-19, human rights and cybersecurity during a tense exchange Monday in the highest-level meetings between the two countries on Chinese soil since Joe Biden became president.

title: Bitcoin, Coinbase, Aon, Tesla: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Bitcoin and cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase jump; Chinese technology companies extend losses. U.S. stock futures slid Monday, suggesting that major Wall Street indexes will retreat from last week's record highs. Here's what we're watching ahead of the opening bell. Read our full markets wrap here.

title: Virtual Comic-Con Sets Back San Diego's Recovery
summary: Resume Subscription. SAN DIEGO-July is typically a make-or-break month for many of this West Coast city's restaurants, bars and trinket shops. Just as the nation's retailers look to turn a profit for the year on Black Friday, small businesses here pin their livelihood on conventions, whose thousands of attendees filter out into the city to spend money.

title: PerkinElmer Buying BioLegend for $5.25 Billion
summary: BioLegend's San Diego campus to become center for research reagent content development for combined company. PerkinElmer Inc. said it is buying BioLegend, which provides life science antibodies and reagents, for $5.25 billion in a combination of cash and stock.

title: The Smart Way to Catch Up on All Your Postponed Doctors' Visits
summary: Many people are rushing to catch up on medical care they missed earlier in the pandemic. Here's how to tackle your personal-health to-do list. Lydia Elle decided to skip her annual physical last year. Her daughter was home doing virtual school, and Ms. Elle had little time to run out for an appointment. She also worried about contracting Covid-19 at a doctor's office.

title: LeVar Burton to Guest Host 'Jeopardy!' as Tryouts Continue
summary: A viral campaign helped the 'Reading Rainbow' star get a guest-host tryout, but fans of the game show are divided over who should be Alex Trebek's successor. When LeVar Burton takes the helm of "Jeopardy!" this week, it will be a sound-the-alarm event for the fans who believe his path-from "Roots" to "Reading Rainbow" to "Star Trek"-ought to culminate in the full-time job of leading America's most elevated game show.

title: Starting Out Remotely: a Q&A With Signify Health's Compliance Chief
summary: Erin Kelly, who started earlier this month, discussed her new role as a compliance officer and starting out in a remote working environment. Healthcare platform provider Signify Health Inc. has named Erin Kelly as its new chief compliance officer. The hiring comes as the company, which offers value-based payment programs and in-home health evaluations for customers such as healthcare plans and systems, pivoted to telehealth during the pandemic. The company, which has offices in Dallas, Connecticut and New York, also is looking to expand.

title: Slushies, Ice Vests and Other Secrets of Staying Cool in a Hot Olympic Triathlon
summary: Resume Subscription. ODAIBA BEACH, Japan-When Team USA's pair of male triathletes jumped into Tokyo Bay for the swimming portion of their race on Monday morning, John Farra was there to play mixologist. As high performance director for USA Triathlon, Farra is in charge of keeping the five Americans cool on the course in this city's punishing heat and humidity.

summary: The singer-songwriter also tells us about learning Italian and his daily smoothie routine.. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Tokyo's Olympic Games Were Supposed to Be in 2020. Japan's Covid Protocols Are Still There.
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Under the lights of the Nippon Budokan arena this weekend, Naohisa Takato elevated all 130 pounds of himself to hero status as he won Japan's first gold of the Olympics.

title: Boeing's Starliner Set to Launch, Giving Company a Do-Over in Space
summary: NASA needs another way to get to the space station; Friday's test comes after failed 2019 attempt. Boeing Co.'s next space launch this week will give it a shot at proving it can still pull off big missions.

title: Covid-19 Surge Prompts Schools to Reconsider Face-Mask Rules for Fall
summary: Districts are sticking with plans to return to in-person learning, but some school mask rules are changing. The rise in Covid-19 cases driven by the Delta variant is prompting school districts across the country to consider changing their face-mask requirements, in an effort to stick to their plans to bring back students for in-person learning this fall.

title: Activision Blizzard Gender-Bias Suit Shows Videogame Culture Remains a Flashpoint
summary: Seven years after GamerGate, allegations of misconduct toward women who work in the sector persist. A gender-bias lawsuit filed by California regulators against Activision Blizzard Inc. has reignited discussion about videogaming culture and whether the industry's treatment of women is toxic.

title: Credit Card Spending Bill Will Come Due
summary: Card companies are enjoying minuscule losses and big spending, but competitive risks loom. Credit-card companies no longer have a spending problem. They've still got a borrowing problem.

title: Katie Ledecky Begins Her Olympics in an Unexpected Color: Silver
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Katie Ledecky's quest for five Olympic medals got under way at Tokyo Aquatic Center on Monday morning. But her first piece of hardware came in an unexpected color: silver.

title: Retailers Have Back-to-School in the Bag
summary: As students return to classrooms, pent-up demand is expected to produce a strong buying season. After more than a year of on-and-off Zoom schooling, parents have a fair bit of back-to-school shopping to do as children return to classrooms. Retailers-both last year's winners and laggards-will need it.

title: Big Oil Companies Push Hydrogen as Green Alternative, but Obstacles Remain
summary: BP, Shell want to make the gas using renewable energy, but doing so remains expensive. Big oil companies have long touted hydrogen energy as a way to reduce carbon emissions. Now they are grappling with how to make that a reality.

title: China's Tutoring Restraint Slams Stocks
summary: Country confirms intention to take drastic steps to curb booming industry. SINGAPORE-China confirmed it would take drastic steps to restrain the country's booming after-school tutoring industry, prompting further selloffs in stocks like New Oriental Education & Technology Group Inc. on Monday.

title: Barclays Overtakes Credit Suisse in Investment Banking
summary: Executives at U.K. bank say collapses of Credit Suisse clients Archegos and Greensill have created rare opportunity to grab market share. Barclays PLC recently overtook Credit Suisse Group AG in investment banking revenue, a sign that the U.K. bank's long, frustrated push to be a major player is making progress thanks in part to the troubles of its Swiss rival.

title: Slate Rounds Up Close to $600 Million for First Credit Fund
summary: The real-estate focused investment firm's new fund includes backing from Goldman Sachs's asset management unit. Real-estate focused Slate Asset Management, which is backed by Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s Petershill arm, has raised nearly $600 million for its first private-credit fund.

summary: The pro golfer tested positive for Covid again-after getting vaccinated. Here's what that could mean for the rest of us.. TOKYO-Jon Rahm keeps testing positive.

title: Hot Used-Car Market Boosts Auto Lenders and Borrowers
summary: Used vehicles are performing more like houses-growing in value. Red-hot demand for used cars is turning the auto-lending world upside down.

title: A Key Gauge of Future Inflation Is Easing
summary: After soaring since October, public and bond-market expectations of inflation have fallen back, suggesting sustained higher prices are less likely. One of the most important signals of future inflation has begun to ease in the past month, a development that should reassure the Federal Reserve in its prediction that the recent inflation surge will prove largely temporary.

title: Demand for Part-Time CFOs Heats Up
summary: Funding bump lets more early-stage companies hire fractional finance chiefs instead of having other executives manage the books. Chief financial officers who work part-time for several companies are in high demand as venture-capital firms pour more money into early-stage startups, creating a gig economy for CFOs.

summary: Resume Subscription. The vaccination drive among adolescents, a critical part of the wider effort to build society-wide immunity to Covid-19, has slowed, as many parents harbor safety concerns.

summary: Plenty of workers want a fresh start now, but a new gig isn't always the answer. Here are things to consider before firing off a farewell email.. It feels like everyone's doing it.

title: Top Billing (Monday Crossword, July 26)
